soc.server

Class SOCBoardAtServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.game.SOCBoard
      • soc.game.SOCBoardLarge
        • soc.server.SOCBoardAtServer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class SOCBoardAtServer
extends SOCBoardLarge
    A subclass of SOCBoardLarge for the server to hold server-only per-game board state, isolate makeNewBoard(SOCGameOptionSet), and simplify that parent class. See SOCBoardLarge for more details. For the board layout geometry, see that class javadoc's "Coordinate System" section.

    Sea board layout: A representation of a larger (up to 127 x 127 hexes) JSettlers board, with an arbitrary mix of land and water tiles. Implements SOCBoard.BOARD_ENCODING_LARGE. Activated with SOCGameOption "SBL".

    A SOCGame uses this board; the board is not given a reference to the game, to enforce layering and keep the board logic simple. Game rules should be enforced at the game, not the board. Calling board methods won't change the game state.

    On this large sea board, there can optionally be multiple "land areas" (groups of islands, or subsets of islands), if SOCBoardLarge.getLandAreasLegalNodes() != null. Land areas are groups of nodes on land; call SOCBoardLarge.getNodeLandArea(int) to find a node's land area number. The starting land area is SOCBoardLarge.getStartingLandArea(), if players must start in a certain area. During board setup, makeNewBoard(SOCGameOptionSet) calls makeNewBoard_placeHexes(int[], int[], boolean, int[], boolean, boolean, int, boolean, boolean, int, SOCGameOption, String, SOCGameOptionSet) once for each land area. In some game scenarios, players and the robber can be excluded from placing in some land areas.

    It's also possible for an island to have more than one landarea (as in scenario SC_TTD).

    To Add a New Board:

    To add a new board layout type, for a new game option or scenario: You'll need to declare all parts of its layout, recognize its scenario or game option in makeNewBoard, and call methods to set up the structure. These layout parts' values can be different for 3, 4, or 6 players.

    A good example is SC_PIRI "Pirate Islands"; see commits 57073cb, f9623e5, and 112e289, or search this class for the string SC_PIRI.

    If you need to move your board layout's coordinates by a few rows or columns, utility script /src/tools/coords-shift.py might be helpful.

    Parts of the new board's layout:

    • Its height and width, if not default; set in getBoardSize(SOCGameOptionSet, int)
    • Its set of land hex types, usually shuffled *
    • Land hex coordinates *
    • Dice numbers to place at land hex coordinates, sometimes shuffled
    • Its set of port types (3:1, 2:1), usually shuffled
    • Its port edge locations and facing directions
    • Pirate and/or robber starting coordinate (optional)
    • If multiple Land Areas, its land area ranges within the array of land hex coordinates
      * Some "land areas" may include water hexes, to vary the coastline from game to game.

    Some scenarios may add other "layout parts" related to their scenario board layout. For example, scenario _SC_PIRI adds "PP" for the path followed by the pirate fleet. See the list of Added Layout Parts documented at SOCBoardLarge.getAddedLayoutPart(String).

    If the new board's scenario game options always disallow moving the pirate ship, add the scenario to soctest.game.TestBoardLayouts.testLayout_movePirateCoastal's skip list.

    Layout placement rules for special situations:

    • If player shouldn't build on an island (like scenario SC_CLVI):
      Don't place that island's hexes in a Land Area: Use LA # 0 when calling makeNewBoard_placeHexes(..).
    • Nodes on hexes having LA # 0 (no land area) aren't legal for settlement placement, and the client will ignore them when generating the legal road edges between legal settlement nodes. So, hexes in LA 0 may be more difficult to build roads across.
    • If an island has more than one Land Area (like scenario SC_TTD):
      After placing non-adjacent areas' hexes on the island, place a 1-hex-wide border zone of land hexes which either have no land area (LA 0), or use the nodesAreInfill parameter of makeNewBoard_placeHexes(..). See above for caveat about LA 0.
      This is because the Land Areas are tracked by their hexes' nodes, not by the hex coordinates themselves, and a node can't be in multiple LAs.
      The client won't notice an "overshared" node that's in multiple LAs, to avoid being too picky and thus brittle, but server unit test soctest.game.TestBoardLayouts will fail layouts having such node inconsistencies in 2.3.00 and newer.
    • Fog-hidden hexes contain some Water (like scenario SC_FOG):
      Such hexes can't be part of the Initial Placement Land Area(s), for settlement placement reasons and because of assumptions in the code that generates Legal Edges. However, the player can be allowed to build to reach them after game play begins.

      During board generation, fog hexes are treated as land hexes: To prevent leaking information about what kind of hex is under the fog, all their corners are legal settlement nodes until revealed as water. For more info, see makeNewBoard_hideHexesInFog(int[], boolean) javadoc.

      While testing: Make sure to reveal a non-coastal water hex that removes edge(s) from the set of legal roads, and confirm that set's still accurate at client after leaving/rejoining the game.

    If any of those situations apply to your new board layout:
    Test to make sure the client sees potential/legal nodes and edges correctly, even if they leave/reconnect during the game: With your layout, follow the test process in /doc/Release-Testing.md section 'Client reconnect when scenario's board layout has "special situations"'.
    Since:
    2.0.00
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>

      • PROP_JSETTLERS_DEBUG_BOARD_FOG

        public static final java.lang.String PROP_JSETTLERS_DEBUG_BOARD_FOG
        Flag property jsettlers.debug.board.fog: When present, about 20% of the board's land hexes will be randomly covered by fog during makeNewBoard(..) generation. Ignored if SOCGameOptionSet.K_SC_FOG is set.
        See Also:
        PROP_JSETTLERS_DEBUG_BOARD_FOG__GOLD, Constant Field Values

      • PROP_JSETTLERS_DEBUG_BOARD_FOG__GOLD

        public static final java.lang.String PROP_JSETTLERS_DEBUG_BOARD_FOG__GOLD
        Flag property jsettlers.debug.board.fog_gold: When present, about 50% of the board's fog hexes will be randomly revealed as gold.

        Can be used independently of PROP_JSETTLERS_DEBUG_BOARD_FOG.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCBoardAtServer

        public SOCBoardAtServer(SOCGameOptionSet gameOpts,
                        int maxPlayers,
                        IntPair boardHeightWidth)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a new server-side Settlers of Catan Board, with the v3 encoding. Size must be passed using boardHeightWidth. Called by SOCBoardAtServer.BoardFactoryAtServer.createBoard(SOCGameOptionSet, boolean, int) to get the right board size and layout based on game options and optional SOCScenario.

        The board will be empty (all hexes are water, no dice numbers on any hex). The layout contents are set up later by calling makeNewBoard(SOCGameOptionSet) when the game is about to begin; see SOCBoardLarge class javadoc for how the layout is sent to clients.

        If the board should have a Visual Shift at the client, this constructor sets Added Layout Part "VS" based on gameOpts/scenario and maxPlayers. See SOCBoardLarge.getAddedLayoutPart(String) javadoc for details on "VS".

        Parameters:
        gameOpts - Game's options if any, otherwise null
        maxPlayers - Maximum players; must be default 4, or 6 from SOCGameOption "PL" > 4 or "PLB"
        boardHeightWidth - Board's height and width. Server-side caller should use a lookup method to determine proper board size for scenario and player count.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if maxPlayers is not 4 or 6, or boardHeightWidth is null

    • Method Detail

      • setNewBoardProgressListener

        public static void setNewBoardProgressListener(SOCBoardAtServer.NewBoardProgressListener li)
        Set or clear this class's sole SOCBoardAtServer.NewBoardProgressListener. The listener field is static, it will be called for all boards.
        Parameters:
        li - Listener to use, or null to remove the current listener if any.

      • drawItemFromStack

        public java.lang.Integer drawItemFromStack()
        Description copied from class: SOCBoardLarge
        If this scenario has a separate stack of dev cards or items waiting to be claimed by any player, draw the next item from that stack. This is not the regular dev card deck used by SOCGame.buyDevCard(), although its items may have come from there during game setup.

        This is called at server, but not at client; client instead receives messages from the server when the player claims such an item. It's declared here in SOCBoardLarge instead of SOCBoardAtServer so that game methods can call it without importing the server-side class.

        In _SC_FTRI, each item is a SOCDevCardConstants card type.

        Overrides:
        drawItemFromStack in class SOCBoardLarge
        Returns:
        The next item from the stack, or null if empty or unused

      • distributeClothFromRoll

        public boolean distributeClothFromRoll(SOCGame game,
                                       SOCGame.RollResult rollRes,
                                       int dice)
        Game action: Distribute cloth to players on a dice roll. Calls SOCVillage.distributeCloth(SOCGame, soc.game.SOCGame.RollResult) for any village(s) with matching dice number. That calls SOCBoardLarge.takeCloth(int), SOCPlayer.setCloth(int), etc. Each player trading with that village gets at most 1 cloth.

        Used for scenario game option _SC_CLVI.

        Parameters:
        game - Game with this board
        rollRes - game's roll results, to add cloth distribution into: Updates SOCGame.RollResult.cloth, SOCGame.RollResult.clothVillages fields
        dice - Rolled dice number
        Returns:
        true if any cloth was distributed

      • movePirateHexAlongPath

        public int movePirateHexAlongPath(int numSteps)
                           throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        For game scenario option _SC_PIRI, move the pirate fleet's position along its path. Updates board's internal index along the path. Calls setPirateHex(newHex, true).

        If the pirate fleet is already defeated (all fortresses recaptured), returns 0.

        Overrides:
        movePirateHexAlongPath in class SOCBoardLarge
        Parameters:
        numSteps - Number of steps to move along the path
        Returns:
        new pirate hex coordinate, or 0
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this board doesn't have layout part "PP" for the Pirate Path.

      • makeNewBoard

        public void makeNewBoard(SOCGameOptionSet opts)
        Shuffle the hex tiles and layout a board. Sets up land hex types, water, ports, dice numbers, Land Areas' contents, starting Land Area if any, and the legal/potential node sets (SOCBoardLarge.getLegalSettlements()). Sets up any Added Layout Parts such as "PP", "CE", "VE", "AL", "N1", etc.

        This is called at server, but not at client; client instead calls methods such as SOCBoardLarge.setLandHexLayout(int[]) and SOCBoardLarge.setLegalSettlements(Collection, int, HashSet[]), see SOCBoardLarge class javadoc.

        Overrides:
        makeNewBoard in class SOCBoardLarge
        Parameters:
        opts - Game options, which may affect tile placement on board, or null. opts must be the same as passed to constructor, and thus give the same size and layout (same SOCBoardLarge.getBoardEncodingFormat()).

      • makeNewBoard_hideHexesInFog

        protected void makeNewBoard_hideHexesInFog(int[] hexCoords,
                                           boolean nodesAreInfill)
                                    throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        For makeNewBoard(SOCGameOptionSet), hide these hexes under SOCBoardLarge.FOG_HEX to be revealed later. The hexes will be stored in SOCBoardLarge.fogHiddenHexes; their SOCBoardLarge.hexLayoutLg and SOCBoardLarge.numberLayoutLg elements will be set to SOCBoardLarge.FOG_HEX and 0.

        After hexes are hidden, calls the SOCBoardAtServer.NewBoardProgressListener if one is registered.

        Does not remove anything from SOCBoard.nodesOnLand or SOCBoardLarge.landAreasLegalNodes. To prevent leaking information about the hex being hidden if it's a SOCBoard.WATER_HEX which is in SOCBoardLarge.landHexLayout, adds all its non-coastal nodes and edges to nodesOnLand, landAreasLegalNodes, and SOCBoardLarge.legalRoadEdges as if it was a land hex. (Ignores Added Layout Part "AL".) When revealed later during game play, SOCBoardLarge.revealFogHiddenHex(int, int, int) will remove those nodes/edges.

        To simplify the bot, client, and network, hexes can be hidden only during makeNewBoard, before the board layout is made and sent to the client.

        Parameters:
        hexCoords - Coordinates of each hex to hide in the fog. Any elements with value 0 are ignored.
        nodesAreInfill - If true, these hexes and nodes are "infill" adjacent to already-placed ones. If any hex's nodes here are already part of a Land Area, will not add those nodes to another LA in SOCBoardLarge.landAreasLegalNodes.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if any hexCoord is already SOCBoardLarge.FOG_HEX within SOCBoardLarge.hexLayoutLg
        See Also:
        SOCBoardLarge.revealFogHiddenHexPrep(int)

      • getLegalSeaEdges

        public static int[][] getLegalSeaEdges(SOCGame ga)
        For scenario game option _SC_PIRI, get the list of Legal Sea Edges arranged for the players not vacant.

        Arranged in same player order as the Lone Settlement locations in Added Layout Part "LS" set up in startGame_putInitPieces(SOCGame): A player number's LSE and LS may differ from game to game, based on which lower-numbered seats are vacant, to avoid spacing gaps on the board.

        Parameters:
        ga - Game data, for SOCGame.maxPlayers and SOCGame.isSeatVacant(int)
        Returns:
        Edge data from PIR_ISL_SEA_EDGES, containing an array for each player from 0 to ga.maxPlayers - 1, where vacant players get empty subarrays of length 0.

        Each player's list is their individual edge coordinates and/or ranges. Ranges are designated by a pair of positive,negative numbers: 0xC04, -0xC0D is a range of the valid edges from C04 through C0D inclusive.

        If game doesn't have SOCGameOptionSet.K_SC_PIRI, returns null.

      • startGame_scenarioSetup

        public static int[][] startGame_scenarioSetup(SOCGame ga)
        For a game that's starting, now that the board layout is known, do any extra setup required by certain scenarios.

        If ! ga.hasSeaBoard, does nothing and returns null.

        In this order:

        • Calls getLegalSeaEdges(SOCGame): In scenario _SC_PIRI, that will return non-null because ship placement is restricted. If so, calls each player's SOCPlayer.setRestrictedLegalShips(int[]).
        • Calls startGame_putInitPieces(SOCGame): Used in _SC_PIRI and _SC_FTRI.
        Parameters:
        ga - Game to set up; assumes SOCGame.startGame() has just been called
        Returns:
        this board layout's getLegalSeaEdges(SOCGame) if placement is restricted, or null

      • startGame_putInitPieces

        public void startGame_putInitPieces(SOCGame ga)
        For scenario game option _SC_PIRI, place each player's initial pieces. For _SC_FTRI, set aside some dev cards to be claimed later at Special Edges. Otherwise do nothing.

        For _SC_PIRI, also calls each player's SOCPlayer.addLegalSettlement(int, boolean) for their Lone Settlement location (adds layout part "LS"). Vacant player numbers get 0 for their "LS" element. (Same per-player arrangement as getLegalSeaEdges(SOCGame))

        Called only at server. For a method called during game start at server and clients, see SOCGame.updateAtBoardLayout().

        Called from startGame_scenarioSetup(SOCGame) for those scenario game options; if you need it called for your game, add a check there for your scenario's SOCGameOption.

        This is called after makeNewBoard(SOCGameOptionSet) and before SOCGameHandler.getBoardLayoutMessage(soc.game.SOCGame). Calls SOCBoardLarge.setAddedLayoutPart(String, int[]) if needed.

        If ship placement is restricted by the scenario, please call each player's SOCPlayer.setRestrictedLegalShips(int[]) before calling this method, so the legal and potential arrays will be initialized.
